content: There was no visible test case for the 12:xx PM edge case so I added another test and reorganized the existing ones a bit so the validators match tests better.

Updated the description to specify what are the range of the possible inputs (e.g., the colon will always be there, the hour will always be two digits, the minute will always be two digits), what is considered a valid 24-hour format, and what is considered a valid 12-hour format.

Added test case that tests just invalid hour, with valid minute, which was missing before.

Input
3:32
Output
3:32 AM

This input should be INVALID since it's not in 24-hour time!
I failed this just now (75%) because of this validator despite getting 100% on test cases.

The input needs to be changed to 03:32 or the answer should be INVALID.

Compare this to 09:38 which is the next test case. 3:32 is invalid.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I did it in C in golf mode, it's interesting.

Nice CoC!

The contribution guidelines state, that every validator should check the same case as the corresponding test. You have some cases where this does not happen. For example Test 3 "AM" and its Validator "Invalid minutes" or Test 5 "AM" and its Validator "Invalid minutes and hours".

As a C# user , I have to convert some substring . I took time but it' s because I maked error . But I don't think beginner know the  substring or Int32.Parse(input); . 

That contribution give me a probleme . I haven't take enough time for reject it but some avanced techniques prevent me to accept it. 

En tant que utilisateur de C# , j'ai du convertir des substring . J'ai pris du temps car j'ai fait des erreurs . Mais je pense pas les débutant connaisent les substring ou Int32.Parse(input);

Cette contribution me posent un problème j'ai pris pas assez de temps pour rejeter mais les techniques avancées m'empechent d'accepter

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because...I ticked all the checkboxes! :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find it as a nice puzzle for beginners, nicely done.
I suggest to add/edit test cases and validators to cover the situations of 1 ≤ minute ≤ 9, hour = 0, and hour = 12.
I'll edit that, thanks for informing me!

Same is true for input "5:59".
It's very frustrating that both of these incorrect tests were hidden as validators.

You need to clarify what "valid" means if you aren't expecting users to enforce 4 digit formats for 24 hour time.
Edited it, thanks for pointing it out.

As a non C# user (I only did a few puzzles on CG with it, and nothing else at all), I do not considerate extracting a substring or converting a string to an int as a challenge, and it is very easy and fast to search and find how to do. I just tried it with C# and have a solution of 3 lines of code.
